description: From Middle English consideren, from Middle French considerer, from Latin considerare.

verbs.description: consider (third-person singular simple present considers, present participle considering, simple past and past participle considered)

examples: Synonyms: bethink, reflect (on); see also Thesaurus:ponder
Consider that we’ve had three major events and the year has hardly begun.
How can you know everything about everything, if you won't consider any dissent?

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To think about something seriously or carefully: to deliberate.

examples: I’m considering going to the beach tomorrow.
Synonyms: deem, regard, think of; see also Thesaurus:deem
Consider yourself lucky, but consider your opponent skillful.
Synonyms: regard, observe; see also Thesaurus:pay attention
She sat there for a moment, considering him.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To take up as an example.
examples: Consider a triangle having three equal sides.

entries.meaning: (transitive, parliamentary procedure) To debate (or dispose of) a motion.
examples: This body will now consider the proposed amendments to Section 453 of the zoning code.

entries.meaning: To have regard to; to take into view or account; to pay due attention to; to respect.
examples: He never seems to consider the feelings of others.
